awd_titl_txt: EARS: Collaborative Research: Crowdsourcing-Based Spectrum Etiquette Enforcement in Dynamic Spectrum Access
awd_abstract_narration:
The radio spectrum is becoming an increasingly valuable natural resource nowadays, while it has been shown that much of the spectrum is underutilized in existing licensed bands. To enhance spectrum utilization, dynamic spectrum access (DSA) has been envisioned as a set of promising new spectrum management paradigms, such as spectrum trading/auction and opportunistic spectrum access. While DSA and programmable cognitive radios enable a much higher flexibility of spectrum access, due to the openness of wireless medium, it is also susceptible to various forms of misuse or abuse. For example, unauthorized transmissions without a valid license, or secondary transmissions that intentionally disobey the interference constraints set by the primary users (radios). The misusers will not only gain higher throughput for themselves, but also harm the efficiency of spectrum access operations of normal users (radios). Therefore, enforcing spectrum access rules or etiquettes is crucial to ensuring the ultimate success of the DSA paradigm. 

This project develops a framework for etiquette and rule enforcing in dynamic spectrum sharing environments. The main idea of the proposed research is to engage community users (radios) to detect misuse, and identify and punish unruly devices. By crowdsourcing the tasks of monitoring neighborhood radio access behaviors to many cognitive radio devices, multiple benefits can be gained: 1) the potentially large number of participating devices can result in much larger detection coverage and accuracy; 2) no pervasive dedicated trusted infrastructure or hardware is needed; and 3) the fact that every device could possibly be a monitoring device leads to a much stronger deterrence to misbehaviors. The interdisciplinary research plan consists of four major components: 1) an optimized crowdsourced passive radio traffic monitoring framework to detect access misbehavior in the vast DSA spectrum; 2) techniques to identify misbehaving cognitive radio devices using physical layer identification, even when the signal waveform can be adaptively modified; 3) techniques for immediate punishment of spectrum misuse through adaptive friendly jamming which exploits multi-functional re-configurable antennas; and 4) incentive mechanism design via auctions to ensure user participation in each task of crowdsourced etiquette enforcement. The success of this project will benefit multiple current and future application domains deploying DSA, especially those that require critical information protection, such as healthcare, transportation, energy, public services, emergency, and military services.

por.por_cntn:
The objective of this project is to develop the theoretical foundation and techniques to leverage crowdsourced measurements from commodity devices to enforce spectrum access rules under the dynamic spectrum access architecture, where spectrum can be utilized opportunistically when there is vacancy.  Major research outcomes from this project include: 1) A series of optimization and online-learning based algorithms for monitoring spectrum misuse/ access violations, either under known or unknown violator traffic statistics, which maximize the effectiveness of crowdsourced spectrum violation monitoring while minimizing the cost of monitoring. (2) A series of new algorithms for identification (fingerprinting) of cognitive radio transmitters based on physical layer signal features, which can cope with changes in signal or device characteristics such as frequency, modulation, bandwidth, temperature, without requiring extensive training data, and methods that crowdsource fingerprinting measurements to a large number of devices to reduce the hardware requirement and cost (e.g., lower the sampling rate). (3) Techniques for enforcing the spectrum access rules using friendly jamming as punishment, which prevents violating devices to communicate with each other while minimizing the impact to normally behaving devices. New algorithms and protocols for secure communications by proactively randomizing the channel using reconfigurable antennas were proposed, which are more secure than existing approaches in terms of stronger resistance against message eavesdropping and modification attacks. The secret communication protocol can be used to achieve more effective friendly jamming. (4) Incentive mechanism design for crowdsourced mobile sensing, which can be applied to incentivize more users/devices to participate in crowdsourced spectrum monitoring for misuse/violation detection and identification.

The research results from this project have been widely disseminated to the research community and impacted the current active research on dynamic spectrum access and cognitive radio networks, spectrum monitoring, crowdsourced sensing, wireless network security, spectrum anomaly detection, device fingerprinting, incentive mechanism design. The research results have been published in prestigious journals and presentations have been made in top conferences, such as IEEE Transactions on Dependable and Secure Computing, IEEE Transactions on Cognitive Communications and Networking, Computer Networks, IEEE International Conference on Computer Communication, ACM Symposium on Information, Computer and Communications Security, IEEE International Symposium on Dynamic Spectrum Access Networks, IEEE Global Communications Conference, etc. A dedicated webpage is maintained by the PI to disseminate the outcomes of this project, including a list of publications. Curriculum development activities integrated the research results into respective course modules at three collaborating institutions (University of Arizona, Virginia Tech, and Colorado School of Mines). In addition, the PI has delivered several seminar talks on the topic of crowdsourcing based spectrum access rule enforcement.
